intro: Let's explore how electric cells work! In this simulation, you can learn about the parts of a cell and how it makes a bulb light up.

questions.question: An electric cell has two terminals. What are they called?
questions.hint: One terminal is marked with a plus sign (+) and the other with a minus sign (-).

questions.question: What happens to the bulb when you close the circuit with a working cell?
questions.hint: Closing the circuit completes the path for the electric current to flow.

questions.question: If you flip the cell so the terminals are swapped, what happens to the bulb?
questions.hint: Think about the direction of current flow and how the cell's terminals must be connected.

questions.question: When you add a second cell to the circuit, what happens to the bulb's brightness?
questions.hint: More cells can provide more electrical energy, but only if the circuit is complete.

questions.question: What happens if you use a burnt-out bulb in a complete circuit?
options: B) It lights up but is dimmer
questions.hint: A burnt-out bulb has a broken filament that stops the current from flowing.

followups: Try changing the cell orientation and see if the bulb still lights up.
Experiment with adding a second cell to see how it affects the bulb's brightness.
summary: An electric cell converts chemical energy into electrical energy. It has a positive and negative terminal. When connected in a complete circuit, it makes a bulb light up. The orientation of the cell matters, and adding more cells can make the bulb brighter.
